questions.text: In the context of the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition Committee (VHSNC), which of the following is the primary responsibility regarding the Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village?

options.label: A
options.text: To manage and fund the operation of the AWC, including salaries and infrastructure.

options.label: B
options.text: To supervise the functioning of the AWC and facilitate its role in improving the nutritional status of women and children.

options.label: C
options.text: To staff the AWC with qualified medical professionals for direct healthcare provision.

options.label: D
options.text: To establish new AWCs in villages that do not have one.

questions.correct_answer: B. To supervise the functioning of the AWC and facilitate its role in improving the nutritional status of women and children.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The VHSNC supervises the functioning of the AWC to improve nutrition and health outcomes for women and children in the village.
  • ➤ The VHSNC supervises the functioning of the AWC to improve nutrition and health outcomes for women and children in the village.

questions.text: An 18-year-old nulliparous woman, Priya from Mumbai, presents with concerns about a gonorrheal infection after being notified by her boyfriend that he tested positive for gonorrhea and negative for chlamydia three days ago. Yesterday, she developed dysuria and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She has no significant past medical history, but she reports a penicillin allergy after developing a non-pruritic, non-painful rash following amoxicillin use 3 months ago. She denies trouble breathing, dizziness, fever, eye pain, or mouth sores. On examination: Purulent discharge from the cervical os No cervical motion tenderness or pelvic pain What is the best next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe a weeklong course of ciprofloxacin

options.label: D
options.text: Reassure the patient and administer ceftriaxone

questions.correct_answer: D. Reassure the patient and administer ceftriaxone
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reassure the patient and administer ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with a mild, delayed maculopapular rash after penicillin exposure can safely receive ceftriaxone. Severe allergic reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, angioedema, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) warrant alternative treatments.
  • ➤ Patients with a mild, delayed maculopapular rash after penicillin exposure can safely receive ceftriaxone.
  • ➤ Severe allergic reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, angioedema, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) warrant alternative treatments.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of acute ischemic stroke is being considered for thrombolytic therapy. Which of the following thrombolytic agents preferentially activates plasminogen bound to fibrin, thereby avoiding systemic fibrinolysis and minimizing bleeding complications?

questions.text: Which of the following are clinical signs of ovulation? Increase in basal body temperature >0.5°F in the second half of the menstrual cycle. Progesterone level >5 ng/mL 7 days before menses. Presence of mittelschmerz. Elevated estrogen levels during the secretory phase of the cycle.

  • ➤ Indicators of ovulation include basal body temperature increase, progesterone rise, and the presence of mittelschmerz.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with chronic pain due to osteoarthritis is prescribed Pentazocine. He is also diagnosed with hypertension and a history of myocardial infarction. Which of the following properties of Pentazocine makes it contraindicated in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: It acts as a full agonist at the Mu receptors, leading to increased risk of myocardial infarction.

options.label: B
options.text: It has opioid antagonist activity at both Kappa and Mu receptors, resulting in a decreased analgesic effect.

options.label: C
options.text: It acts as a partial agonist at the Mu receptors and can increase heart rate and blood pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a complete opioid antagonist, which causes severe withdrawal symptoms in chronic opioid users.

questions.correct_answer: C. It acts as a partial agonist at the Mu receptors and can increase heart rate and blood pressure.
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist with partial agonist activity at Mu receptors that can increase heart rate and blood pressure, making it contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or hypertension.
  • ➤ Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist with partial agonist activity at Mu receptors that can increase heart rate and blood pressure, making it contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or hypertension.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with fever, chills, and rigors on postoperative day 8 following a total abdominal hysterectomy. options.label: B
options.text: The investigation of choice for confirming a pelvic abscess is ultrasonography.

options.label: C
options.text: Pigtail catheter drainage is the preferred treatment for pelvic abscesses.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient is presenting with chief complains of tingling and numbness in lateral 3 & 1/2 fingers. Tinel’s sign and Phalen’s test are positive. What will be the diagnosis?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely experience in Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS) is tingling and numbness in the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers (indicative of median nerve involvement), along with positive Tinel’s sign and Phalen’s test that support compression of the median nerve at the wrist.
  • ➤ The most likely experience in Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS) is tingling and numbness in the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers (indicative of median nerve involvement), along with positive Tinel’s sign and Phalen’s test that support compression of the median nerve at the wrist.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, Ramesh from Mumbai, is admitted for acute alcoholic pancreatitis. His APACHE II score of 20 indicates severe disease. Over 48 hours, he has received 10 liters of IV fluids, but his condition has deteriorated: Respiratory failure → Intubated, on high PEEP and FiO₂ Rising creatinine (from 1.2 mg/dL to 2.2 mg/dL) and decreased urine output Elevated JVP, bilateral lung crackles, tense abdominal distension, and pitting edema Abdomen: Diffusely tender, diminished bowel sounds Urinalysis: Normal, ruling out intrinsic renal causes (e.g., glomerulonephritis, hematuria, pyuria, or casts) What is the best next step to establish the cause of AKI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Measurement of bladder pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is a life-threatening cause of AKI in critically ill patients receiving aggressive fluid resuscitation. Diagnosis: Measure bladder pressure (>25 mmHg is diagnostic). Treatment: Immediate decompression (paracentesis or surgery) to prevent permanent organ damage.
  • ➤ Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is a life-threatening cause of AKI in critically ill patients receiving aggressive fluid resuscitation.
  • ➤ Diagnosis: Measure bladder pressure (>25 mmHg is diagnostic).
  • ➤ Treatment: Immediate decompression (paracentesis or surgery) to prevent permanent organ damage.

questions.text: A 23-year-old cricketer had an avulsion of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon of his ring finger. This was diagnosed early and despite proximal migration, he had it reinserted with a button technique. Six months later, he complains that he can’t close his fingers tightly over a cricket ball. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Quadrigia effect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The complaint of not being able to close fingers tightly is most consistent with the Quadrigia effect, which happens after tendon repairs, especially of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, leading to difficulty in flexing the fingers due to altered force distribution across all fingers.
  • ➤ The complaint of not being able to close fingers tightly is most consistent with the Quadrigia effect, which happens after tendon repairs, especially of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, leading to difficulty in flexing the fingers due to altered force distribution across all fingers.

questions.text: Regarding the contents of the Suprasternal space of burns, which of the following statements are correct? The suprasternal space contains the jugular venous arch formed by the anterior jugular veins. The suprasternal space contains the external jugular vein. The interclavicular ligament is part of the contents of the suprasternal space. The sternal head of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) is a content of the suprasternal space.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The suprasternal space of Burns contains the jugular venous arch , interclavicular ligament , and sternal head of the SCM , but does not include the external jugular vein , which is located in the supraclavicular space .
  • ➤ suprasternal space of Burns
  • ➤ jugular venous arch
  • ➤ interclavicular ligament
  • ➤ sternal head of the SCM
  • ➤ external jugular vein
  • ➤ supraclavicular space

questions.text: A premature infant is diagnosed with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). The following fundus findings are noted during progression of the disease. Arrange them in the correct order of occurrence: a) Partial retinal detachment b) Demarcation line c) Elevated ridge d) Total retinal detachment e) Extraretinal neovascularization extending into vitreous
questions.correct_answer: A. b, c, e, a, d
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In retinopathy of prematurity, the correct order of progression of fundus findings is: Demarcation line → Elevated ridge → Extraretinal neovascularization extending into vitreous → Partial retinal detachment → Total retinal detachment.
  • ➤ In retinopathy of prematurity, the correct order of progression of fundus findings is: Demarcation line → Elevated ridge → Extraretinal neovascularization extending into vitreous → Partial retinal detachment → Total retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with complaints of loss of appetite, frequent nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and weight loss for several months. Upon interaction with the physician, the child demonstrates slurred speech and ataxic gait. Clinical examination reveals hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. The child is diagnosed with type B Niemann–Pick disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Niemann–Pick disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Deficiency of sphingomyelinase enzyme in tissues

options.label: B
options.text: Deficiency of LCAT enzyme in tissues

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are correct

questions.correct_answer: B. Deficiency of LCAT enzyme in tissues
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niemann–Pick disease is caused by a deficiency of the sphingomyelinase enzyme due to mutations in the SMPD1 gene, leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the liver, spleen, and central nervous system. It is distinct from LCAT deficiency, which is associated with a different disorder called Norum’s disease.
  • ➤ Niemann–Pick disease is caused by a deficiency of the sphingomyelinase enzyme due to mutations in the SMPD1 gene, leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the liver, spleen, and central nervous system.
  • ➤ It is distinct from LCAT deficiency, which is associated with a different disorder called Norum’s disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is scheduled for an elective cholecystectomy. The surgical team discusses the classification of wounds and associated risks of surgical site infections (SSIs). Clean wounds, such as in thyroid surgery, have no role for prophylactic antibiotics unless an implant is placed. Clean-contaminated wounds involve entry into the GI or GU system without significant inflammation and have an SSI risk of 3–9%. Contaminated wounds, like emergency appendectomies, carry a higher SSI risk of 20% when prophylactic antibiotics are used. Dirty wounds, such as abscess drainage, have the highest risk of SSIs, even with prophylactic antibiotics.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wound classification determines the risk of surgical site infections, with SSI risk increasing from clean to dirty wounds, and prophylactic antibiotics significantly reduce infection rates in contaminated and dirty wounds.
  • ➤ Wound classification determines the risk of surgical site infections, with SSI risk increasing from clean to dirty wounds, and prophylactic antibiotics significantly reduce infection rates in contaminated and dirty wounds.

questions.text: A 26-year-old software engineer is brought to the emergency by his family with a 1-week history of decreased sleep (sleeping only 2-3 hours/night), excessive talking, making grand plans to start multiple companies, and beliefs that he is being followed by his colleagues who are jealous of his "special abilities". questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute mania with psychotic features , the preferred treatment is a combination of a second-generation antipsychotic (e.g., olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine) + a mood stabilizer (e.g., valproate, lithium) . Valproate is especially useful for agitated or mixed episodes and has a faster onset than lithium.
  • ➤ For acute mania with psychotic features , the preferred treatment is a combination of a second-generation antipsychotic (e.g., olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine) + a mood stabilizer (e.g., valproate, lithium) . Valproate is especially useful for agitated or mixed episodes and has a faster onset than lithium.
  • ➤ acute mania with psychotic features

questions.text: A 33-year-old man, Rajesh from Mumbai, visits the clinic for routine follow-up after undergoing pneumatic dilation for esophageal achalasia. He reports significant improvement in dysphagia and nocturnal regurgitation. His medical history includes borderline hypertension and an anxiety disorder. He previously smoked (5 pack-years) and has a family history of Sjögren’s disease and lymphoma. He is currently taking omeprazole and clonazepam. On examination: BP: 135/85 mmHg Pulse: 67/min BMI: 30 kg/m² Systemic examination: Unremarkable Over the next 10 years, which of the following conditions is he at the highest risk for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Squamous cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with achalasia have a significantly increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma due to prolonged food stasis, bacterial overgrowth, and chronic mucosal irritation. Long-term surveillance with periodic endoscopy is crucial in monitoring for early malignant changes.
  • ➤ Patients with achalasia have a significantly increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma due to prolonged food stasis, bacterial overgrowth, and chronic mucosal irritation. Long-term surveillance with periodic endoscopy is crucial in monitoring for early malignant changes.
  • ➤ esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
  • ➤ periodic endoscopy

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to the risk of gastrointestinal perforation and worsening respiratory distress.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female who has had a history of Crohn's disease for many years, underwent ileal resection, now presents with megaloblastic anemia despite adequate dietary intake of vitamin B12. options.label: C
options.text: Haptocorrin binding to vitamin B12 is defective, leading to reduced transport.

options.text: Intrinsic factor is not secreted, preventing B12 binding in the stomach.

Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ileal resection disrupts cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis, impairing the absorption of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex and leading to B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man, Ravi from Pune, diagnosed with Crohn’s disease, presents with persistent diarrhea for the past 3 months following ileal resection for small-bowel obstruction. He reports 4-5 loose bowel movements daily, significantly disrupting his daily activities and studies. He denies fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, or weight loss. He had a perianal abscess treated with metronidazole 7 months ago. Physical examination is unremarkable, apart from a well-healed abdominal scar. Laboratory findings: Mild anemia (Hb: 12.0 g/dL) Hypokalemia (K+: 3.4 mEq/L) Normal ESR (10 mm/h) Normal B12 levels Which of the following is most likely to improve his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholestyramine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bile acid malabsorption is a common cause of chronic diarrhea following ileal resection, as the terminal ileum plays a crucial role in bile salt reabsorption. Excess bile acids in the colon lead to secretory diarrhea, which can significantly impact daily life. Cholestyramine, a bile acid sequestrant, effectively binds bile acids and alleviates symptoms. Early recognition and appropriate management are essential to improving quality of life in post-resection patients.
  • ➤ Bile acid malabsorption is a common cause of chronic diarrhea following ileal resection, as the terminal ileum plays a crucial role in bile salt reabsorption.
  • ➤ Excess bile acids in the colon lead to secretory diarrhea, which can significantly impact daily life.
  • ➤ Cholestyramine, a bile acid sequestrant, effectively binds bile acids and alleviates symptoms.
  • ➤ Early recognition and appropriate management are essential to improving quality of life in post-resection patients.

The drug of choice is β-blockers such as propranolol. Other treatment options include anticholinergics and benzodiazepines .

questions.text: Consider the following statements about Benzodiazepine use: Statement 1: The duration of action of diazepam is longer than alprazolam Statement 2: Lorazepam is preferred in liver disease Statement 3: Clonazepam has the highest potency among benzodiazepines Statement 4: Elderly patients should be started on half the adult dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Clonazepam is potent but not the most potent benzodiazepine , and elderly patients should be started on half the adult dose to reduce the risk of excessive sedation and falls. Proper selection and dosing can optimize efficacy while minimizing side effects.

  • ➤ elderly patients should be started on half the adult dose

questions.text: Which of the following combinations is incorrect regarding second messengers? cAMP is used by vasopressin (V2) for water reabsorption. questions.text: A 64-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and heart failure is started on digoxin therapy. He also takes a thiazide diuretic to manage his edema. What is the most important factor to monitor to reduce the risk of digoxin toxicity in this patient?

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding as shown below: Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basophilic stippling in red blood cells, which appears as blue dots under the microscope, is characteristic of lead poisoning. It occurs due to the accumulation of ribosomal material within RBCs when lead interferes with heme synthesis.
  • ➤ Basophilic stippling in red blood cells, which appears as blue dots under the microscope, is characteristic of lead poisoning.
  • ➤ It occurs due to the accumulation of ribosomal material within RBCs when lead interferes with heme synthesis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with limp. X-ray of the pelvis was taken. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fibrous dysplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paget's disease is unlikely due to the patient's young age. Multiple myeloma is unlikely because it's very rare in young individuals and typically presents with systemic symptoms. Osteopoikilosis is unlikely as it is asymptomatic and would not cause limping. Fibrous dysplasia is the most likely diagnosis due to its characteristic appearance on X-ray and its association with bone pain, deformities, and limping in young individuals.
  • ➤ Paget's disease is unlikely due to the patient's young age.
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is unlikely because it's very rare in young individuals and typically presents with systemic symptoms.
  • ➤ Osteopoikilosis is unlikely as it is asymptomatic and would not cause limping.
  • ➤ Fibrous dysplasia is the most likely diagnosis due to its characteristic appearance on X-ray and its association with bone pain, deformities, and limping in young individuals.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with Parkinson’s disease has been experiencing motor fluctuations despite being on levodopa therapy. Her physician adds entacapone to her treatment regimen. Which of the following best describes the role of entacapone in levodopa therapy?

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the peripheral breakdown of levodopa, leading to prolonged plasma levels

options.label: C
options.text: It directly stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: It converts levodopa into its active form in the brain

questions.correct_answer: B. It decreases the peripheral breakdown of levodopa, leading to prolonged plasma levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A synthetic polyribonucleotide with the repeating sequence CAA is translated in a cell-free protein synthesizing system, resulting in three homopolypeptides: polyglutamine, polyasparagine, and polythreonine. The codon for glutamine and asparagine are CAA and AAC, respectively. Based on this information, which of the following triplets codes for threonine?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In this case, the ACA triplet codes for threonine in the context of a repeating synthetic polyribonucleotide sequence. Codons for glutamine (CAA) and asparagine (AAC) have been provided, leaving ACA as the correct codon for threonine.
  • ➤ In this case, the ACA triplet codes for threonine in the context of a repeating synthetic polyribonucleotide sequence.
  • ➤ ACA triplet
  • ➤ threonine
  • ➤ Codons for glutamine (CAA) and asparagine (AAC) have been provided, leaving ACA as the correct codon for threonine.
  • ➤ ACA

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presented with impairment of intellectual function and alterations in behaviour. His family reported progressive disorientation and memory loss over the last 6 months. There is no family history of dementia. The patient was tentatively diagnosed with Alzheimer disease (AD). Which of the following best describes the pathological mechanism underlying Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by the infectious β-sheet form of a host-cell protein.

options.label: B
options.text: It results from the accumulation of denatured proteins that have random conformations.

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with the accumulation of amyloid precursor protein.

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with the deposition of neurotoxic amyloid β peptide aggregates.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is associated with the deposition of neurotoxic amyloid β peptide aggregates.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alzheimer’s disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid β peptide aggregates , which are derived from the amyloid precursor protein (APP) . These aggregates form neurotoxic plaques, contributing to neuronal dysfunction and cognitive decline.
  • ➤ Alzheimer’s disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid β peptide aggregates , which are derived from the amyloid precursor protein (APP) .
  • ➤ accumulation of amyloid β peptide aggregates
  • ➤ amyloid precursor protein (APP)
  • ➤ These aggregates form neurotoxic plaques, contributing to neuronal dysfunction and cognitive decline.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer is treated with PD-1 inhibitors as part of their immunotherapy regimen. The tumor's ability to evade the immune system is primarily through the upregulation of PD-L1 and PD-L2. What is the underlying role of these factors in immune evasion?

options.text: PD-L1 and PD-L2 enhance the production of cytokines that activate the immune system to destroy tumor cells.

options.text: PD-L1 and PD-L2 are upregulated by PD-1 receptor activation, which prevents T-cell recognition of tumor antigens.

questions.correct_answer: A. PD-L1 and PD-L2 prevent the activation of T-cells by binding to PD-1 receptors on T-cells.
